III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following area:
• Methodist Children's Home (MCH) is currently approved to utilize Crisis
Prevention Institute's physical management model. However, MCH requested on
06/30/2025 to change their physical management model to Therapeutic Crisis
Intervention (TCI) with an effective date of 10/01/2025. This change was approved
by Department of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) on 07/03/2025. MCH is
responsible for notifying DCWL prior to 10/01/2025 if there are barriers to
reaching their requested transition to TCI.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following area:
• R 400.4115 First aid; CPR. Rule states a person certified within the preceding 36
months in first aid and within the preceding 24 months in age-appropriate
cardiopulmonary resuscitation by the American Red Cross, the American Heart
2

Association, or an equivalent organization or institution approved by the
department shall be on duty at all times when 1 or more children are present.
Methodist Children's Home has identified staff to meet this rule requirement. It is
recommended that all supervisors and direct care workers be trained and are up
to date in CPR training.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted 12 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
• 2024 Renewal Inspection – CAP approved 08/10/2024
R400.4113(1)(i) was cited when one employee file reviewed had a
clearance completed 30 days prior to the employee’s date of hire. MCH
developed a new hire clearance tracking form. This issue is resolved
because there were no issues with employee clearances during this
inspection period.
• 2025SIC0001427 – CAP approved 08/21/2024
R400.4142(1)(a) was cited when there was a delay in a youth’s medical
treatment for his fractured hand. MCH updated their emergency medical
and on call policy and procedure and reviewed the updated policy and
procedure with staff. CAP is completed.
• 2024SIC0001795 - CAP approved 01/09/2025
R400.4158(1)(a)(iv) was cited when a staff made inappropriate
comments. This staff is no longer employed at MCH. Incident reporting
policy and procedure was revised to include staff are to report concerns
about staff using inappropriate language. The revised incident reporting
policy and procedure was reviewed during team meetings. CAP is
completed.
• 2024SIC0001698 – CAP approved 03/14/2025
R400.4159(5) was cited when a supervisor attempted to physically
manage a youth on his own. Supervisor was placed on a performance
improvement plan and retrained in verbal de-escalation. During team
meeting, it was discussed that CPI utilizes a two staff physical
management hold. MCH instituted a vignette training on how to handle
escalated situations. Vignette training on how to handle escalated
situations will occur twice a year for staff. CAP remains active.
• 2025SIC0000145 – CAP approved 03/31/2025
R400.4158(1)(a)(iv) was cited when a staff used profanity towards a
youth. Relationship building policy and procedure was revised to include
3

appropriate language usage. Staff were retrained in small role play
groups on the revised policy and procedure. Relationship building role
play training will occur twice a year for staff. CAP remains active.
• 2025SIC0000241 - CAP approved 04/14/2025
R400.4131(1) was cited when a therapist reported an incident to
administration instead of following mandated reporter requirements.
Therapist and clinical team were retrained on mandated reporting
expectations and responsibilities. Mandated reporter training will occur
twice a year for staff. R400.4109(1)(c) was also cited for not having a
policy and procedure on what type of music a youth may download. MCH
updated their music, television, and video games policy and procedure to
prohibit violent, sexual, and mature rated material. The revised policy and
procedure was reviewed in team meetings. CAP remains active.
• 2025SIC0000304 – CAP approved 05/30/2025
R400.4158(1)(a)(ii) was cited when a staff pushed a youth. This staff is
no longer employed at MCH. R400.4159(5) was also cited because the
staff did not use an authorized physical management method.
Supervisors are expected to monitor staff de-escalation techniques and
coach staff as needed. MCH created and posted visual guides in the
youth cottages that outline de-escalation and physical management
protocol. CAP remains active.
• 2025SIC0000630 - CAP approved 07/09/2025
R400.4150(3) was cited when foster care workers were not notified each
time a youth truanted from MCH. Staff were retrained on the notification
and documentation requirements when a youth truants. CAP remains
active.
• 2025SIC0000633 – CAP approved 07/09/2025
R400.4109(1)(c) was cited when a staff failed to write an incident report
about two youths in a physical altercation. The staff involved is no longer
employed at MCH. Staff were retrained in incident report writing criteria
and expectations. Supervisor reports now have a prompt for incident
reports. Staff are required to check in with the supervisor at the end of
their shift to ensure incident reports are completed. CAP remains active.
• 2025SIC0000617 - CAP approved 07/16/2025
R400.4160(b) was cited when a staff did not use a protective or
supportive stance with a youth. This staff is no longer employed at MCH.
R400.4163(5) was cited when this staff failed to write an incident report.
The staff that witnessed this incident was verbally disciplined and
retrained using the video of the incident. The video of this incident along
with other video clips are being used as a teaching tool on how incidents
should be handled. CAP remains active.
• 2025SIC0000640 – CAP approved 08/19/2025
R400.4159(5) was cited when a staff did not use a CPI method in
physically managing a youth. This staff is no longer employed at MCH.
MCH is changing their physical management model from CPI to TCI
4

effective 10/01/2025 to assist in emergency situations with their youth
population. CAP remains active.
• 2025SIC0000594 - CAP approved 08/29/2025
R400.4158(1)(a)(iv) was cited when a staff threatened to hit a youth
back. This staff is no longer employed at MCH. Staff were trained on self-
awareness of their emotional triggers and appropriate responses. Team
meetings discussed how staff can support each other. Self-awareness of
one’s emotions was added to MCH’s new employee training curriculum.
CAP remains active.
MCH diligently works on their CAPS, which are monitored for six months from the
date of approval. DCWL continues to review and monitor each active CAP. There are
no concerns with MCH’s compliance with completed and active CAPS.
Financial Overview
There are no concerns with Methodist Children's Home December 2023 annual
financial audit and budget.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
This is not applicable to Methodist Children's Home.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Assessment completed on 08/20/2025 was reviewed. It
highlights Methodist Children's Home is working with a more challenging youth
population due to the changes in their contract with the youth admission process.
Methodist Children's Home provided additional trainings in behavioral interventions
and crisis management to assist staff in working with the youths.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Three staff were randomly selected for interviews at Methodist Children's Home
Society. Each staff stated the training provided was adequate. Each staff correctly
explained variable interval eye on checks and mandated reporting.
Three youths were randomly selected for interviews at Methodist Children's Home
Society. Each youth stated they have their own bedroom and are responsible for
keeping their bedroom clean. Each youth stated they have adequate food and
snacks, are able make phone calls to approved persons, and did not express
concerns with their placement at Methodist Children's Home.
5

Description of Agency Walk Through
Methodist Children's Home welcomes visitors at the building located at the front of
the campus. This building houses a reception area, administrative offices, and
meeting rooms. Moving past this building is a large, wooded campus. Near the
center of the campus is an administrative building with offices and meeting rooms.
The youths reside in two cottages located southwest of the administrative building
near the campus center. Each cottage has a kitchen, dining area, two common
areas, showers and bathrooms, and individual youth bedrooms. A large staff desk
area is located across from the bedrooms. The outdoor area has picnic tables,
playground equipment, and plenty of open space for use.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
